description: Ran in my Nike Free Run+ because my calves and foot were not feeling happy. I felt a hard ridge under the ball of the right foot.  It was very distracting and my foot eventually started hurting.
Suffering from RBES... "Running Barefoot Exuberance Syndrome".

I think I know why I hurt my foot... trying too hard to do ball-heel-ball caused me to point my toes too much and slap the ball down too hard.  I have also been moving through the foot roll motion too slowly.  The elite runners and my 3-year-old daughter (kids are handy sometimes) seem to land "almost flat" but really it's just barely front- or mid-foot before the heel touches down.  Now... to rest.

"Extensor Tendonitis" sounds like the cause of my foot pain.  I thought the pain was originating inside my foot but then I discovered it is painful to the touch on the top of my foot just behind my toes and when I pull my toes "up".  Ibuprofen has been working wonders.  In the first link, the picture has a blue arrow pointing right at my pain...
TOFP = Top of Foot Pain, seems to follow after Calve Pain in new barefoot runners (exactly what happened to me).  http://gobarefooting.wordpress.com/2010/04/21/injury-top-of-the-foot-pain/

Use Cotton Balls to Treat Top of Foot Pain Tendonitis

title: Fast barefoot run
description: I was just going to do a nice, easy morning run... but then two shod runners turned onto the trail at the same time as me.  The guy gave some neighborly advice: "Don't stub your toe on a tree root."  The female runner said "We're just jealous."   She actually had a nice midfoot strike, even though she was wearing marshmallow shoes.  I hung in behind them for a while, and when I turned onto 8th Ave I just started cruising (the other runners had stopped to rest)... and kept cruising... and kept cruising.  Pretty sure this is my fastest barefoot run yet.  There were quite a few people out today, so I contributed some good barefoot exposure to the world.  My leg muscles were "twitchy" afterwards.

Conjecture:  the reason that human short term memory tends to be able retain 7 items... because that is the most optimal count to ensure obstacle avoidance (sticks, rocks, roots, ...) while running at hunting pace.  It explains why we can look ahead on the trail (not down at our feet) and still somehow avoid stepping on sharp things.  Now, someone go research this.  :)

Saw some info apparently from Arthur Lydiard's book... get your REST people!
"We do know a bit more about the appropriate length of the recovery 
period, thanks to research carried out with marathon runners. A study 
carried out by Michael Warhol and his colleagues at Harvard Medical 
School and Tufts University uncovered extensive damage in marathoners' 
leg muscles immediately after the 26.2-mile race (broken cell fibres, 
swollen cells, mangled membranes, degenerated mitochondria, and 
damaged blood vessels were present). Repair of this sorry state of 
affairs took about four weeks, and in some runners it took even longer 
('Skeletal Muscle Injury and Repair in Marathon Runners after 
Competition,' American Journal of Pathology, vol. 118, pp. 331-339, 
1985).  True, not all endurance athletes are marathon runners, but 
subsequent research showed that moderate endurance training (about 31 
miles of running per week - with no marathon running) can produce 
similar damage in 33 per cent of runners and slightly heavier training 
(48 miles per week with no marathoning) can induce comparable damage 
in the majority of runners ('Structural and Ultrastructural Changes in 
Skeletal Muscle Associated with Long-Distance Training and Running,' 
International Journal of Sports Medicine, vol. 10, pp. S156-159, 
1989). Thus, we can conclude that almost all serious runners need a 
recovery period . . . "

Started getting a knot/cramp in my quad during lap 2 (before Larabar and NUUN). Fueled up for lap 3 and the knot went away.  I think this is my longest run ever in my whole life (even going back to college XC days) and I did it barefoot.  Tired but happy, I feel prepared for what comes next.

The Adidas Kanadia are on sale at Sports Authority for $50, and they have clearance section in the back with Kanadia 2 from last year in less boring colors. I wanted to get new shoes since my feet have expanded too much for my Nike Frees and the Frees just have too much heel lift.  I could not wait for all of the new minimalist shoes coming out in spring 2011.

They did well on the sandy trails.  The downside is that my left foot developed some PF-like pain and caused something like ITBS in my right leg. These caused me to run the next loop in different shoes.  Despite Gainesville having four 5ks on the same day, that Saturday trail running group was out in force.

title: San Felasco - Hammock Cutoff loop
description: Switched to VFF.  Was going to run another outer loop but quickly realized just how bad the VFF Bikila are on sandy trails.  I quickly hopped over and decided to do Hammock Cutoff.  After a time developed some pain in my right arch.

title: San Felasco - Hammock Cutoff loop barefoot
description: Tired by this loop.  Walked some parts and enjoyed the thick sand.  Barefoot helped the pains developed from previous loops go away.  Dry trails are much crunchier/sharper than moist trails and leaf litter was hiding many pokey objects. Did not enjoy this barefoot trail run very much.  Good mileage for the day which is what I wanted.
Could not fight the pull any longer... ordered a pair of GoLite Flash Lite running shoes from Zappos.

Shoes, shoes, shoes... so the GoLite Flash Lites I ordered were too big.  Guess having a shoe that is actually foot-shaped means I can go back down to my *real* shoe size.  Glad Zappos has free return shipping.  Since I was ordering again, I could not resist getting a couple other shoes to try... the Mizuno Wave Universe 3 and the Saucony ProGrid Kinvara.

title: stationary bike

I have a house full of shoes from Zappos and have to decide what shoes to wear for this weekend's half marathon.

I left him (as we agreed) and then I started to push it. I was able to pick off runners the whole way back. Developed a knot in my right quad muscle.  Started pumping the gatorade at every aid station, the quad didn't end up being an issue.  Felt like I finished fairly strong.  The new shoes (MWU3) did fine.

title: Warm enough to run barefoot!
description: It seems best for me to work on form issues without shoes on.  Pushing the hips forward / out plus keeping my trailing foot closer to the ground (instead of coming up so far under my butt) seems to be working... my front foot lands more under me than in front of me and it is way easier to maintain 180 cadence.  It also makes it hard to run slow.  :)   It *will* be nice when the sidewalks are free of acorns, nut shells, and other fall debris.

title: Harris Branch
description: VFF and Barefoot.  The Bikilas continue to want to rub a raw spot on the inside of my feet just above the arches... took them off and carried them before too much damage was done.

title: Gave the RunAmocs another try
description: I was pleasantly surprised that I didn't have any of the "big toe pressure" issues that I used to get in my RunAmoc moccasins.  My conversion from forefoot to midfoot apparently keeps my toe from jamming up in the front of the moc.  I also wore them much looser around the ankle and this was not a problem, either. Traction was good even on wet boardwalk. They were plenty warm this morning (with socks) and felt great all around.

title: Gave the huarache sandals another try
description: I thought that since my feet were warmed up I'd be able to go sockless with the sandals.  My toes got cold rather quickly and the thin sandals did not insulate from the cold ground.  I hate cold toes.  Traction was not as good as the RunAmocs on wet boardwalk.  The good news is that again my forefoot to midfoot conversion seems to make these more comfortable to wear (not so much friction in between the toes).

I think total mileage for the trip was around 6 miles.  Also did a lot of hiking in the El Yunque national rain forest in my 4mm cherry huarache sandals.  We didn't get above 700m (2300 feet) of elevation, but all of the trails were very steep down and up.

title: Hatchet Creek Tract trails
description: Hatchet Creek Tract is part of the Newnans Lake Conservation Area (north side of HWY 26). I had some free time today for a second run, decided to go exploring since I have never run there before.  There are no facilities despite what is shown on the map.  Had a nice strong breeze the whole time bringing in cloud cover. I think it would have been hot and miserable otherwise. The trails are nice and wide (and flat), this might make a good location for a group trail run. There is of course some sugar sand but really not bad, most trails are covered in leaves or pine needles or planted in grass. The Yellow loop is a convenient 5k. Taking a map along was very helpful, I would have had trouble without it.  Wore my NB MT00 sockless, had no issues.  Lesson of the day: Top of your water bottle when you get the chance.  I drank some of mine on the way there and didn't refill from my jug before leaving my car.

Eventually turned around in frustration on two different occasions as the trail seemed to just stop or at least wasn't marked well enough to continue. title: mostly treadmill - running study day 2
description: Today was the session running in shoes, my Altra Instincts. I now have a disc full of high speed video and a bunch of data to look over. Interestingly, it looks like me running barefoot requires more energy than in cushioned shoes. Temper that with some form issues that seem more pronounced in those same shoes.

I am wearing the measurement gear and marker dots, Altra Instincts, ready to start running on the treadmill. The running study at UF is still looking for a few more runners. http://www.ortho.ufl.edu/research/studies/barefoot-running

title: long tempo run
description: Trying to correct some of my minor form issues that I noticed in the high speed video I received from the UF Ortho study.  The two big things were 1. I had asymmetric arm carriage 2. I had completely lost the "falling forward" pattern. I noticed while running tonight that falling forward encourages "popping" the feet back up off the ground more quickly. I remember that! But I had not been doing it. I wore my Altra Sampsons for the first time in a while. I think my previous Achilles complaints from these shoes stemmed from the fact that I was doing it wrong. Better form = no pains. It also means faster pace with less effort.

I plan to do a long run tomorrow so I intended to just run a little to stay loose with a nice little run in my Moc3s. A couple miles turned into 4 miles and then I bumped into Diane's morning running group so I ran with them for a while. Headache went away during the run and as always, a nice run seems to reset my bodily systems to "level".

title: 2x long greenway route
description: Actually felt really good at the start since it was nice and cool. It started to heat up around 10am which definitely affected the back half of my run. Experimenting with marathon fuels, this morning was honey + blackstrap molasses which worked great. I was moving well and feeling good. Unfortunately the "sugar" was all gone by the 2nd lap and I crashed hard shortly after 2 hours. It seems like once I start taking sweets I will have to keep it going in. I will have to ponder this since most of my morning runs are in the fasted state and I don't normally bonk that hard.

I need to get that back into my routine.

description: Did 4 reps, only 2 minutes run recovery in between each. Splits; 2:01, 1:52, 1:50, 1:47.

Track training of long intervals at race pace, 2. doing my Achilles tendon therapy consistently, 3. improving my running form (mostly arm swing),  4. consuming bone broth and whole foods,  5. sleeping!   The bloody awesome weather certainly helps (temps in the high 50s this morning!).  Broke 100 miles in my Merrell Trail Gloves and they are still in great shape.
After a great week of training, I did it... I signed up for my first marathon (Jacksonville Bank in December).

description: Longest run of my whole life! Wasn't feeling perfect, I had some stomach distress yesterday and this morning probably due to some "unusual" famers' market greens I ate yesterday. Took fuel along (mostly honey). I guess it helped, but I still hit a wall at mile 20. Legs just quit, couldn't lift them. It also warmed up a lot by the time I shuffled in a smidge before noon. Thought I was running easy for the first half but maybe still going too fast (mostly 8 minute miles with a few faster sections which should be alright since my breathing was easy the whole time, but now I'm less confident about my target marathon race pace). Marathoners are CRAZY for running that far. ;)  Tested race day equipment: RaceReady shorts with pockets, Inov-8 Bare-X Lite 150, gel containers, and my Florida Track Club singlet. Also carried water but I won't do that on race day.

title: All over San Felasco
description: A long day of trail running at San Felasco in the heat wearing my Merrell Vapor Gloves. I started the morning by exploring the hiking trails on the south side of Millhopper Road. Then I followed blue blaze trail to a service road, crossed the gate into the wilderness area, and ended up on horse trails on the north side of the park. Lots of mountain bikes out today. I wandered on curvy singletrack to the north parking area to refill my water bottles and cool down. I was hot and tired by this point (3 hours in and approaching noon), so I wanted to avoid the singletrack on the way back. I needed to get to the bridges near the Soggy Bottom / CreekSide loops to hop back on the horse trails and find that gate. Never did find my way. Next time I will take a map. After getting lost, using up all my food and gels, and almost running out of water, I decided to cross the wilderness swamp that I had used in years past (follow the powerlines). I didn't need to wade through anything more than ankle-deep water (whew!). I did a lot walking during that last hour. I was glad to arrive back at my car with cold water and food waiting for me. Today was a nice adventure (despite the biting flies and ticks), and I saw a couple of hawks, a big wise old owl, some deer (including a cute little fawn), and a large herd of feral pigs. Love the Vapor Gloves.

description: I was getting ready for my LONG run this morning when I turned around to find my youngest daughter sitting there in her running clothes. She said "I want to run with you!" How could I say "no" to that?  We ran around our neighborhood together in the dark for a little bit before I sat her down with breakfast and then I finished packing up to hit the trails of San Felasco. I ran from the south side hiking trails to the north side horse trails. I explored some of the mountain bike trails such as "Hidden Rise". I only saw two groups of riders and otherwise had the north side trails to myself. I am kind of estimating pace and distance, but this was definitely my lifetime longest run ever!   Weather was nice with a breeze and light mist much of the morning. Nature today included a snake that I almost stepped on, I think it was a cottonmouth! Now, two weeks of recovery before my 50k race.
